messages.content: Hi, I'm trying to set up a new React project with TypeScript. Can you help me with the initial configuration?

I'd be happy to help you set up a React project with TypeScript. You can use Create React App with the TypeScript template by running this command in your terminal: `npx create-react-app my-app --template typescript`

This will create a new project with all the necessary TypeScript configurations already set up for you.
Thanks! That worked. Now I'm wondering what folder structure is recommended for a medium-sized application?

For a medium-sized React application, here's a recommended folder structure:
```
src/
  components/       # Reusable UI components
    Button/
    Form/
    Layout/
  pages/            # Page components
  hooks/            # Custom React hooks
  services/         # API calls and data services
  utils/            # Helper functions
  context/          # React context providers
  types/            # TypeScript interfaces and types
  assets/           # Images, fonts, etc.
  styles/           # Global styles
```

This structure keeps your code organized as the application grows. You might want to add more folders based on your specific needs.

I'm getting a CORS error when trying to fetch data from my API. The error says 'Access to fetch at 'http://myapi.com/data' from origin 'http://localhost:3000' has been blocked by CORS policy.' How can I fix this?

CORS errors occur when your browser prevents your frontend from making requests to a different domain than the one serving your app. Here are a few solutions:

1. **Backend solution (recommended)**: Configure your API server to include the proper CORS headers. Add these to your server responses:
   ```
   Access-Control-Allow-Origin: http://localhost:3000
   Access-Control-Allow-Methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE
   Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Content-Type
   ```

2. **Temporary development solution**: Use a proxy in your development environment. If you're using Create React App, add this to your package.json:
   ```json
   "proxy": "http://myapi.com"
   ```
   Then change your fetch URLs to relative paths like `/data` instead of `http://myapi.com/data`.

The first option is better for production environments.

I tried the proxy approach but I'm still getting errors. Here's my package.json:
```json
{
  "name": "my-app",
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "private": true,
  "proxy": "http://myapi.com",
  ...
}
```
And my fetch code: `fetch('/data').then(res => res.json())`
The setupProxy.js solution worked! Thanks so much for your help.

How can I improve the performance of my React app?
Consider using React.memo and useCallback to prevent unnecessary re-renders.
Should I use GraphQL or REST for my new project?
GraphQL is great for complex queries and reducing over-fetching, but REST is simpler and more mature.
What are the best practices for unit testing in React?
Use Jest and React Testing Library for testing components and hooks.
Should I use CSS-in-JS or traditional CSS for styling my React app?
CSS-in-JS offers scoped styles and dynamic theming, but traditional CSS is simpler and has better performance.
What are the steps to deploy a React app to Netlify?
Connect your GitHub repository to Netlify, set up build settings, and deploy.
